results.title: New Arts Complex Aims to Build Community in Detroit
results.abstract: Anthony and JJ Curis are turning a church, its rectory and a city block into a cultural center and a legacy park for the artist Charles McGee.

multimedia.caption: The Detroit gallerists JJ Curis, left, and her husband, Anthony, outside the former Good Shepherd Catholic Church and rectory. They are transforming the buildings into a new contemporary arts complex with galleries, a library and workshop space to contribute to the city’s artistic renaissance.
multimedia.copyright: Sarah Rice for The New York Times

results.title: When ‘Boo!’ Is Only the Beginning
results.abstract: What does it take to scare the candy corn out of someone? Performers at two of New York’s hallowed haunted attractions explain the secrets behind the shocks.
results.byline: By Alexis Soloski and Erik Tanner

multimedia.caption: Keenan Loughney, a nurse at Headless Horseman in Ulster Park, N.Y. While some haunted houses use trained actors, most fill their ranks with enthusiastic amateurs.

results.title: Loose and Boxed Ammunition Found at Scene of Alec Baldwin Shooting
results.abstract: Court papers did not specify what kind of ammunition detectives recovered from a movie set where the actor had fatally shot a cinematographer with a gun he was told did not contain live rounds.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley

multimedia.caption: Alec Baldwin was told the gun he was rehearsing with contained no live rounds when it discharged on a movie set, killing the cinematographer. He spoke on the phone outside the Santa Fe County Sherriff’s Office on Thursday after speaking with investigators.
multimedia.copyright: Jim Weber/Santa Fe New Mexican, via Associated Press

results.abstract: As the pandemic forced most players online, the problem of cheating consumed the game’s highest levels. Top players say a tight-lipped culture is finally changing.

results.title: Apocalypse Now-ish (Cocktails, Anyone?)
results.abstract: Are we ready for a pandemic novel? Gary Shteyngart, the author of “Our Country Friends,” thinks so.

multimedia.caption: “The constant state where terrible things are happening to every single member of society, where you can’t escape, that’s going to be the new normal,” Gary Shteyngart said. “So we have to change the way we write.”

results.abstract: The historian Kevin Boyle weaves stories of war, sex and civil rights into a narrative that argues for a different view of a momentous decade and the years that preceded it.

results.title: FSG Promotes Mitzi Angel to President
